projects.title: X-Ray Tracer
projects.description: We have developed a generic X-ray tracing toolbox based on Geant4, a generic simulation toolkit. By leveraging the facilities available on Geant4, we are able to design and analyze complex X-ray optical systems. In this article we describe our toolbox, and describe how it is being applied to support the development of silicon pore optics for IXO.

contributors.headline: Principal Scientist at cosine | measurement systems

projects.title: Remote Sensing Simulator
projects.description:
The Remote Sensing Simulator models the performance of a number of payload instruments for any orbit and or celestial body. RSS is a software tool that offers you a user friendly and fast way to predict the outcome of remote sensing instrumentation. The user can provide input for the response functions and define one or more performance indicators for the mission and instrument. After configuration the performance is integrated over the mission duration and orbit to determine the scientific return.
I am the main author and maintainer of the RSS.

contributors.headline: Principal Scientist at cosine | measurement systems

projects.title: L01B processor for the Tropomi mission
projects.description: Tropomi is a hyperspectral remote sensing instrument covering bands from the ultraviolet to the short-wave infrared. It will be the payload of the European Space Agency's Sentinel 5 Precurson mission, due t be launched in 2015. I am seconded to the KNMI (Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute) where I work with the L01B processor team on issues related to statistical issues related to the calibration of the instrument and data analysis algorithms.

contributors.headline: Principal Scientist at cosine | measurement systems

projects.title: Interplanetary Electron Model
projects.description:
A new model of the radiation environment around Jupiter has been developed by cosine and the Surrey Space Centre (UK). The model, which accounts for the electron spectrum induced by that planet’s strong magnetic field, is being used by the European Space Agency, and other space agencies around the world, to study the safety of satellite instrumentation.

Space is a hostile environment not only for man, but also for the instruments aboard satellites. In particular, space instrumentation must be protected against the adverse effects of cosmic electrons and other charged particles, that can damage the sophisticated optical and electronic components that instruments are made of. In order to take adequate countermeasures it is important to know the intensity and energy distributions of the particles along the path followed by the satellite. To this end models have been developed, and are routinely used as input into the design of spacecraft shields.

The European Space Agency has collected many of the available models related to the space environment in the Space Environment Information System (SPENVIS). Through SPENVIS spacecraft engineers and scientists can estimate the amount of radiation that a satellite encounters when moving across the Solar System.

The new model developed by cosine and its UK partner has been included in SPENVIS since September 2011. It estimates the spatial, temporal, and spectral distribution of the electrons accelerated by the powerful Jovian magnetic field. Once accelerated these electrons move across the Solar System along the solar magnetic field lines, and are a weak but measurable component of the cosmic radiation across the heliosphere. The predictions of the model have been found to be in good agreement with the electron measurements carried out by spacecraft in orbit around the Earth.

The Jupiter model is part of a suite of tools developed to model the interplanetary electron spectrum, also developed by this team.

I lecture for three days to the students of the Master in Physics, specialization Space Science and Technology, covering topics related to photon detectors for space applications, from the infrared to gamma-rays.
